data.text: The point where Mike Leigh was able to take the heavily improvised, frequently comedic television plays about the British working-class he'd been honing for a decade and merge them with the casually harrowing emotional sensitivity and gritty kitchen sink realism stylization he had clearly been building towards. Observing the bleak, barren, and confused existence of a depressed and impoverished East End family (and a few neighborhood punks) as they listlessly wander the streets, flats, pubs, laundromats, and unemployment offices of Thatcher-era austerity. Leigh is obviously very good at generating authentic environments for actors to find poetry in minute calibrations of mundane situations/behavior (and this has two excellent early performances from a very young Tim Roth and Gary Oldman), but he also displays a real skill for the claustrophobic framing of the drab London public-housing location work and for when to include bursts of the pitchy, clangy score as a moody interlude. The interchangeably abusive and intimate dynamic between the confident brother and the slow one... Think the Safdies have seen this one?
